narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project will generate a significant amount of scientific data, including de-identified demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data (structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS) from 110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls. The estimated amount of data includes tabular demographic/clinical data and multi-modal MRI imaging files for each participant, resulting in a substantial dataset. Data needed to create a global unique identifier for the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) will also be collected.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected scientific data, including tabular demographic/clinical data and MRI imaging data, will be preserved and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate secondary research use, enhance collaboration among researchers, and accelerate discoveries in the field. Sharing these data will also promote transparency, reproducibility, and verification of research findings.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: 
Data dictionaries defining variables and codes used in the tabular data
Study protocols outlining procedures for data collection and MRI acquisitions
Data collection instruments (e.g., questionnaires, surveys)
README files describing the content, format, and any usage notes for the shared data

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools and software are needed to access or manipulate the shared scientific data. Specifically, MRI imaging data will require software capable of handling neuroimaging file formats (e.g., NIfTI). Examples of such software include FSL, AFNI, and FreeSurfer. These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories.

Common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata to enable interoperability of datasets and resources. The project will adhere to the standards recommended by the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) for MRI imaging data and tabular clinical/demographic data. This includes using standardized ontologies for demographic and clinical variables, and adhering to the BIDS (Brain Imaging Data Structure) standard for organizing and describing MRI datasets.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from the project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository recommended by the NIH for sharing human subjects data. This choice ensures that the data are stored in a secure, accessible, and widely recognized platform.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers provided by the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). Each dataset shared through the NDA will be assigned a DOI (Digital Object Identifier), facilitating easy citation and access.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will remain available for at least 10 years after the end of the project to allow for extended research use and verification of findings.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While maximizing data sharing is a priority, factors affecting subsequent access include the need to protect participant privacy and confidentiality. Given that participants have provided consent for broad data sharing, limitations on access will primarily be related to ensuring compliance with regulations protecting human subjects, such as HIPAA.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be strictly controlled but will follow the guidelines set by the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) for sharing de-identified data. Researchers will need to register with the NDA and agree to terms of use, which include respecting the privacy and rights of research participants.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will be de-identified. This includes removal of direct identifiers (e.g., names, dates of birth) and indirect identifiers that could lead to participant identification. Additionally, data use agreements will be implemented to ensure that recipients of the data adhere to privacy and confidentiality protections.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Plan will be monitored and managed by the Lead Principal Investigator (PI), who is responsible for the day-to-day oversight of data management activities. The PI, in collaboration with the research team and institutional review board (IRB), will ensure that all aspects of data collection, storage, sharing, and protection are conducted according to this Plan and relevant regulatory guidelines. Oversight will occur on a quarterly basis during active data collection phases and annually thereafter to ensure ongoing compliance and address any issues related to data management and sharing.
